elements.content: A new coordination synthon, Zn···NO2 recognition, is used in the synthesis of a layered porphyrin coordination polymer (Zn-5,15-di(4-nitrophenyl)-10,20-di(p-tolyl)-porphyrin, 1-Zn) with 44 topology. This solid is thermally stable and incorporates nitrobenzene molecules between the layers to form 1-Zn − PhNO 2 . The Zn···NO2 recognition exists in 1-Zn and 1-Zn − PhNO 2 ; it is formed by coordination bonding between a Zn2+ ion embedded in a porphyrin core and one of the O-atoms of the nitro group. The structure of 1-Zn − PhNO 2 is also layered and contains 44 networks such as those found in 1-Zn. The two structures, however, differ significantly in several intra- and interlayer parameters. Despite these differences, removal of nitrobenzene from the crystals of 1-Zn − PhNO 2 yields crystalline 1-Zn. When soaked in nitrobenzene, these desolvated 1-Zn crystals yield crystalline 1-Zn − PhNO 2 . These reversible solid-to-solid transformations demonstrate the robustness of Zn···NO2 recognition in holding the 44 networks together in the solid state.
elements.clean_text: A new coordination synthon, Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition, is used in the synthesis of a layered porphyrin coordination polymer (Zn-5,15-di(4-nitrophenyl)-10,20-di(p-tolyl)-porphyrin, 1-Zn) with 44 topology. This solid is thermally stable and incorporates nitrobenzene molecules between the layers to form 1-Zn - PhNO  2 . The Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition exists in 1-Zn and 1-Zn - PhNO  2 ; it is formed by coordination bonding between a Zn2+ ion embedded in a porphyrin core and one of the O-atoms of the nitro group. The structure of 1-Zn - PhNO  2  is also layered and contains 44 networks such as those found in 1-Zn. The two structures, however, differ significantly in several intra- and interlayer parameters. Despite these differences, removal of nitrobenzene from the crystals of 1-Zn - PhNO  2  yields crystalline 1-Zn. When soaked in nitrobenzene, these desolvated 1-Zn crystals yield crystalline 1-Zn - PhNO  2 . These reversible solid-to-solid transformations demonstrate the robustness of Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition in holding the 44 networks together in the solid state.

elements.content: Layered coordination polymers 1-Zn and 1-Zn − PhNO 2 are prepared using a new coordination synthon termed Zn···NO2 recognition. These materials (a) can be reversibly transformed into each other in the solid state through intercalation and deintercalation, (b) are thermally stable up to 400 °C, (c) soluble in organic solvents, and (d) intercalate nitrobenzene molecules in preference to chloroform, toluene, chlorobenzene, and bromobenzene.
elements.clean_text: Layered coordination polymers 1-Zn and 1-Zn - PhNO  2  are prepared using a new coordination synthon termed Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition. These materials (a) can be reversibly transformed into each other in the solid state through intercalation and deintercalation, (b) are thermally stable up to 400 °C, (c) soluble in organic solvents, and (d) intercalate nitrobenzene molecules in preference to chloroform, toluene, chlorobenzene, and bromobenzene.

elements.content: Coordination polymers containing porphyrin moieties are important targets in crystal engineering because they exhibit unique optical, photochemical, and catalytic properties. Previously, a variety of two- and three-dimensional porphyrin coordination polymers have been created; most of these networks are built by carboxy, hydroxy, aza, cyano, and other well-known ligands. Porphyrin moieties in these solids are connected by strong and directional metal−ligand coordination bonds. A number of porous porphyrin solids, termed porphyrin sponges, have also been made using van der Waals interactions. We noted that nitro groups form close contacts with metal ions embedded in the porphyrin core and wished to explore the ability of this weak interaction in forming extended network structures. Here, we report our initial results in the use of Zn···NO2 recognition as a coordination synthon to prepare porphyrin-based layered coordination polymers that possess predictable topology and that can selectively intercalate nitrobenzene molecules between the layers.
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers containing porphyrin moieties are important targets in crystal engineering because they exhibit unique optical, photochemical, and catalytic properties. Previously, a variety of two- and three-dimensional porphyrin coordination polymers have been created; most of these networks are built by carboxy, hydroxy, aza, cyano, and other well-known ligands. Porphyrin moieties in these solids are connected by strong and directional metal-ligand coordination bonds. A number of porous porphyrin solids, termed porphyrin sponges, have also been made using van der Waals interactions. We noted that nitro groups form close contacts with metal ions embedded in the porphyrin core and wished to explore the ability of this weak interaction in forming extended network structures. Here, we report our initial results in the use of Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition as a coordination synthon to prepare porphyrin-based layered coordination polymers that possess predictable topology and that can selectively intercalate nitrobenzene molecules between the layers.

elements.content: Compound 1, 5,15-di(4-nitrophenyl)-10,20-di(p-tolyl)-porphyrin, was synthesized in two steps from the corresponding aldehydes. Condensation of p-nitrobenzaldehyde with excess pyrrole gave 5-(4-nitrophenyl)dipyrromethane, which on further reaction with p-tolualdehyde followed by oxidation yielded free base 1. Metalation of 1 with zinc acetate gave the compound 1-Zn (Figure a). This metalloporphyrin, a charge-neutral compound, dissolved freely in organic solvents such as chloroform and dichloromethane. Purple-colored crystals of 1-Zn suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from a chloroform solution at 20 °C.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1, 5,15-di(4-nitrophenyl)-10,20-di(p-tolyl)-porphyrin, was synthesized in two steps from the corresponding aldehydes. Condensation of p-nitrobenzaldehyde with excess pyrrole gave 5-(4-nitrophenyl)dipyrromethane, which on further reaction with p-tolualdehyde followed by oxidation yielded free base 1. Metalation of 1 with zinc acetate gave the compound 1-Zn (Figure a). This metalloporphyrin, a charge-neutral compound, dissolved freely in organic solvents such as chloroform and dichloromethane. Purple-colored crystals of 1-Zn suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from a chloroform solution at 20 °C.

elements.content: (a) Molecular structure of1-Zn. (b and c) Zn···NO2 recognition in 1-Zn and 1-Zn − PhNO 2 . Color scheme:  Zn-magenta; O-red; N-blue; and C-gray. Notice octahedral coordination around Zn2+ and differences in thermal ellipsoids of metal bound and free O-atoms.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Molecular structure of1-Zn. (b and c) Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition in 1-Zn and 1-Zn - PhNO  2 . Color scheme: Zn-magenta; O-red; N-blue; and C-gray. Notice octahedral coordination around Zn2+ and differences in thermal ellipsoids of metal bound and free O-atoms.

elements.content: Crystal structure of1-Zn. (a) 44 Networks formed by Zn···NO2 recognition. p-Tolyl groups and H-atoms are omitted. (b) Interlayer stacking. Notice interdigitated packing and offset of layers. H-atoms are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of1-Zn. (a) 44 Networks formed by Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition. p-Tolyl groups and H-atoms are omitted. (b) Interlayer stacking. Notice interdigitated packing and offset of layers. H-atoms are omitted.

elements.content: Compound 1-Zn contains two p-nitrophenyl groups at alternate meso positions on the porphyrin ring; it is designed to have two NO2 groups in trans geometry and no other functional groups that can potentially form coordination bonds. Crystals of 1-Zn belong to the space group P21/n with the molecules located on inversion centers. As expected, the NO2 groups interact with Zn2+ ions through one of the oxygen atoms. It is well-known that tetracoordinated Zn2+ ions enclosed in the porphyrin core frequently form one or two additional bonds with axial ligands. Figure b shows the distorted octahedral coordination around Zn2+ in 1-Zn. The four pyrrolic N atoms form Zn−N bonds of nearly equal length (2.032−2.052 Å); two nitro groups form longer Zn···O bonds (2.521 Å) above and below the plane of the porphyrin ring. These longer contacts constitute weak coordination bonds and allow the free dissolution of the compound in organic solvents.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1-Zn contains two p-nitrophenyl groups at alternate meso positions on the porphyrin ring; it is designed to have two NO2 groups in trans geometry and no other functional groups that can potentially form coordination bonds. Crystals of 1-Zn belong to the space group P21/n with the molecules located on inversion centers. As expected, the NO2 groups interact with Zn2+ ions through one of the oxygen atoms. It is well-known that tetracoordinated Zn2+ ions enclosed in the porphyrin core frequently form one or two additional bonds with axial ligands. Figure b shows the distorted octahedral coordination around Zn2+ in 1-Zn. The four pyrrolic N atoms form Zn-N bonds of nearly equal length (2.032-2.052 Å); two nitro groups form longer Zn⋅⋅⋅O bonds (2.521 Å) above and below the plane of the porphyrin ring. These longer contacts constitute weak coordination bonds and allow the free dissolution of the compound in organic solvents.

elements.content: The following observations demonstrate the bonding nature of Zn···O contacts. (1) The Zn···O distance is significantly shorter than the sum of the corresponding van der Waals radii (2.521 vs 2.910 Å). (2) The metal bound N−Oa bond in the NO2 group is longer than the free N−Ob bond (1.246 vs 1.171 Å). (3) The geometry at the Zn2+ ion is octahedral. (4) Finally, thermal motion of the metal bound Oa atom (U eq = 0.070 Å2) is lower than that of the free Ob atom (U eq = 0.128 Å2). If the Oa atom is not involved in bonding with Zn2+ ion, we would expect it to have higher thermal motion because the N−Oa bond is longer than the N−Ob bond.
elements.clean_text: The following observations demonstrate the bonding nature of Zn⋅⋅⋅O contacts. (1) The Zn⋅⋅⋅O distance is significantly shorter than the sum of the corresponding van der Waals radii (2.521 vs 2.910 Å). (2) The metal bound N-Oa bond in the NO2 group is longer than the free N-Ob bond (1.246 vs 1.171 Å). (3) The  geometry at the Zn2+ ion is octahedral. (4) Finally, thermal motion of the metal bound Oa atom (U eq = 0.070 Å2) is lower than that of the free Ob atom (U eq = 0.128 Å2). If the Oa atom is not involved in bonding with Zn2+ ion, we would expect it to have higher thermal motion because the N-Oa bond is longer than the N-Ob bond.

elements.content: Crystal structure of1-Zn − PhNO 2 . (a) 44 Networks formed by Zn···NO2 recognition. p-Tolyl groups and H-atoms are omitted. (b) Interlayer stacking showing the intercalation of nitrobenzene between the layers. Notice longer interlayer separation and shorter layer offset compared to 1-Zn (Figure ). Nitrobenzene molecules are plotted in lighter colors. H-atoms are omitted.

(b) Interlayer stacking showing the intercalation of nitrobenzene between the layers. Notice longer interlayer separation and shorter layer offset compared to 1-Zn (Figure ). Nitrobenzene molecules are plotted in lighter colors. H-atoms are omitted.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of (a)1-Zn grown in chloroform solution, (b) 1-Zn − PhNO 2 grown in chloroform/nitrobenzene solution, (c) 1-Zn obtained by heating the 1-Zn−PhNO 2 to 350 °C, (d) mixture of 1-Zn and 1-ZnPhNO 2 obtained by soaking the crystals of desolvated 1-Zn in nitrobenzene, and (e) 1-Zn obtained by heating of the mixture in (d) to 350 °C. Note in (c) and (e) that the diffraction patterns of desolvated and re-desolvated crystals correspond to that of 1-Zn. Note in (d) the peaks corresponding to 1-Zn (open, blue circles) and 1-Zn − PhNO 2 (filled, red circles). Microscopic images of the crystals corresponding to the diffraction patterns are shown on the left. The image next to (d) is taken while the crystals are soaking in nitrobenzene. The image next to (e) shows some precipitation on crystal faces. The occlusion of smaller particles on well-grown crystals occurred when the soaked crystals are scraped on to a filter paper for drying. Morphology of the crystals remained unchanged during the heating in TGA chamber.
elements.clean_text: 4  Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of (a)1-Zn grown in chloroform solution, (b) 1-Zn - PhNO  2  grown in chloroform/nitrobenzene solution, (c) 1-Zn obtained by heating the 1-Zn-PhNO 2  to 350 °C, (d) mixture of 1-Zn and 1-ZnPhNO  2  obtained by soaking the crystals of desolvated 1-Zn in nitrobenzene, and (e) 1-Zn obtained by heating of the mixture in (d) to 350 °C. Note in (c) and (e) that the diffraction patterns of desolvated and re-desolvated crystals correspond to that of 1-Zn. Note in (d) the peaks corresponding to 1-Zn (open, blue circles) and 1-Zn - PhNO  2  (filled, red circles). Microscopic images of the crystals corresponding to the diffraction patterns are shown on the left. The image next to (d) is taken while the crystals are soaking in nitrobenzene. The image next to (e) shows some precipitation on crystal faces. The occlusion of smaller particles on well-grown crystals occurred when the soaked crystals are scraped on to a filter paper for drying. Morphology of the crystals remained unchanged during the heating in TGA chamber.

elements.content: Figure a shows the layered structure of 1-Zn. Within the layer, each molecule donates two Zn···O bonds through NO2 groups and accepts two bonds through Zn2+ ions, leading to a two-dimensional network with 44 topology. Molecules are inclined at an angle of 42.3° with respect to the mean plane of the layer, and partially project the p-tolyl groups into the interlayer space (Figure b). Adjacent layers are stacked on each other such that they adopt an interdigitated packing, which maximizes the close packing between the layers. A separation of 9.806 Å and an offset of 2.784 Å between adjacent layers accommodate such interdigitated packing. The overall structure has a packing efficiency of 69.0%.
elements.clean_text: Figure a shows the layered structure of 1-Zn. Within the layer, each molecule donates two Zn⋅⋅⋅O bonds through NO2 groups and accepts two bonds through Zn2+ ions, leading to a two-dimensional network with 44 topology. Molecules are inclined at an angle of 42.3° with respect to the mean plane of the layer, and partially project the p-tolyl groups into the interlayer space (Figure b). Adjacent layers are stacked on each other such that they adopt an interdigitated packing, which maximizes the close packing between the layers. A separation of 9.806 Å and an offset of 2.784 Å between adjacent layers accommodate such interdigitated packing. The overall structure has a packing efficiency of 69.0%.

elements.content: Noting the lamellar structure of 1-Zn and the potential space between p-tolyl groups in the interlayer region, we explored the guest inclusion properties of 1-Zn. Slow evaporation of a chloroform solution of 1-Zn and nitrobenzene yielded solvated crystals containing 1-Zn and nitrobenzene in a 1:2 ratio; this solvate is referred to as 1-Zn − PhNO 2 . We made several unsuccessful attempts to prepare the solvates of 1-Zn containing chlorobenzene, bromobenzene, and toluene. When we crystallized 1-Zn with nitrobenzene and one or more of these aromatic molecules, crystals of only 1-Zn − PhNO 2 were formed. Crystallization of 1-Zn from varying molar ratios of chloroform and nitrobenzene (100:1 to 0:100) also led to the exclusive crystallization of 1-Zn − PhNO 2 . These observations indicate that compound 1-Zn exhibits high selectivity for the inclusion of nitrobenzene.
elements.clean_text: Noting the lamellar structure of 1-Zn and the potential space between p-tolyl groups in the interlayer region, we explored the guest inclusion properties of 1-Zn. Slow evaporation of a chloroform solution of 1-Zn and nitrobenzene yielded solvated crystals containing 1-Zn and nitrobenzene in a 1:2 ratio; this solvate is referred to as 1-Zn - PhNO  2 . We made several unsuccessful attempts to prepare the solvates of 1-Zn containing chlorobenzene, bromobenzene, and toluene. When we crystallized 1-Zn with nitrobenzene and one or more of these aromatic molecules, crystals of only 1-Zn - PhNO  2  were formed. Crystallization of 1-Zn from varying molar ratios of chloroform and nitrobenzene (100:1 to 0:100) also led to the exclusive crystallization of 1-Zn - PhNO  2 . These observations indicate that compound 1-Zn exhibits high selectivity for the inclusion of nitrobenzene.

elements.content: In the crystal structure of 1-Zn − PhNO 2 (space group P21/c), the key structural features of 1-Zn are retained. These features include the Zn···NO2 recognition (Figure c), layered structure with 44 topology (Figure a), and stacking of the layers (Figure b). The inclusion of nitrobenzene molecules between the layers, however, imposes certain changes in intra- and interlayer parameters. In 1-Zn − PhNO 2 , porphyrin molecules are tilted at a steeper angle (48.2°) with respect to the mean plane of the layer to project p-tolyl groups into interlayer space to a greater extent. Layers are stacked at longer separation (11.289 Å) and shifted by shorter offset (0.851 Å) to create rectangular channels along [010]; solvated nitrobenzene molecules are located in these channels. The Zn···O bonds are longer (2.722 Å); concurrently, the differences in the N−O bond lengths (1.231 vs 1.216 Å) and thermal motions (U eq, 0.068 vs 0.090) between metal-bound and free O atoms are smaller. Despite these differences, the Zn···O contacts in 1-Zn − PhNO 2 show all the bonding characteristics outlined above.
elements.clean_text: In the crystal structure of 1-Zn - PhNO  2  (space group P21/c), the key structural features of 1-Zn are retained. These features include the Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition (Figure c), layered structure with 44 topology (Figure a), and stacking of the layers (Figure b). The inclusion of nitrobenzene molecules between the layers, however, imposes certain changes in intra- and interlayer parameters. In 1-Zn - PhNO  2 , porphyrin molecules are tilted at a steeper angle (48.2°) with respect to the mean plane of the layer to project p-tolyl groups into interlayer space to a greater extent. Layers are stacked at longer separation (11.289 Å) and shifted by shorter offset (0.851 Å) to create rectangular channels along [010]; solvated nitrobenzene molecules are located in these channels. The Zn⋅⋅⋅O bonds are longer (2.722 Å); concurrently, the differences in the N-O bond lengths (1.231 vs 1.216 Å) and thermal motions (U eq, 0.068 vs 0.090) between metal-bound and free O atoms are smaller. Despite these differences, the Zn⋅⋅⋅O contacts in 1-Zn - PhNO  2  show all the bonding characteristics outlined above.

elements.content: The packing efficiency of 1-Zn − PhNO 2 with and without the nitrobenzene molecules is 69.7 and 52.7%, respectively. Considering that the overall network structure in both solvated and unsolvated crystals is similar, a difference of 16.3% (69.0−52.7%) between the packing efficiency of 1-Zn and guest-free 1-Zn − PhNO2 is fairly significant, and this fact demonstrates the reliability of Zn···NO2 recognition as a coordination synthon.
elements.clean_text: The packing efficiency of 1-Zn - PhNO  2  with and without the nitrobenzene molecules is 69.7 and 52.7%, respectively. Considering that the overall network structure in both solvated and unsolvated crystals is similar, a difference of 16.3% (69.0-52.7%) between the packing efficiency of 1-Zn and guest-free 1-Zn - PhNO2  is fairly significant, and this fact demonstrates the reliability of Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition as a coordination synthon.

elements.content: Significant intermolecular interactions are not found among nitrobenzene molecules though they are confined to the interlayer region. These guest molecules do, however, form C−H···O and C−H···π interactions with 4-nitrophenyl and p-tolyl rings of the host molecules. The presence of solvated nitrobenzene in the bulk sample is confirmed by powder X-ray diffractometry (Figure b), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA, Figure a); see the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: Significant intermolecular interactions are not found among nitrobenzene molecules though they are confined to the interlayer region. These guest molecules do, however, form C-H⋅⋅⋅O and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions with 4-nitrophenyl and p-tolyl rings of the host molecules. The presence of solvated nitrobenzene in the bulk sample is confirmed by powder X-ray diffractometry (Figure b), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA, Figure a); see the Supporting Information.

elements.content: TGA plots of (a) the solution grown crystals of1-Zn − PhNO 2 and (b) the mixture of 1-Zn and 1-Zn − PhNO 2 obtained by soaking the crystals of 1-Zn in nitrobenzene for 2 h. The 23.3% weight loss in (a) corresponds to the complete desolvation of nitrobenzene from 1-Zn − PhNO 2 (calculated weight loss:  23.6%). The 18.5% weight loss in (b) indicates that the mixture contains 74.4% of 1-Zn − PhNO 2 and 25.6% of 1-Zn.
elements.clean_text: 5  TGA plots of (a) the solution grown crystals of1-Zn - PhNO  2  and (b) the mixture of 1-Zn and 1-Zn - PhNO  2  obtained by soaking the crystals of 1-Zn in nitrobenzene for 2 h. The 23.3% weight loss in (a) corresponds to the complete desolvation of nitrobenzene from 1-Zn - PhNO  2  (calculated weight loss: 23.6%). The 18.5% weight loss in (b) indicates that the mixture contains 74.4% of 1-Zn - PhNO  2  and 25.6% of 1-Zn.

elements.content: Crystals of 1-Zn − PhNO 2 subjected to guest removal appear shiny and crystalline; 1H NMR analysis showed that these desolvated crystals contained only 1-Zn. We monitored the removal of guest molecules by TGA (Figure a), which showed that complete loss of nitrobenzene molecules occurred at 100−150 °C. The desolvated crystals were cooled to room temperature in the TGA instrument and used for powder X-ray diffraction analysis immediately. Interestingly, guest removal reverted the structure of the solvate to that of the unsolvated form of 1-Zn (Figure c). It should be noted that compounds 1-Zn and 1-Zn − PhNO 2 melt above 400 °C; the desolvated crystals are formed by solid-to-solid phase transition, not by cooling of the melt. We have not established the mechanism of this phase transition. We also observed desolvation of 1-Zn − PhNO 2 optically on a Fisher−Jones melting point apparatus. The crystals remained intact with no apparent change in morphology during the whole heating cycle (from 25 to 300 °C and back to 25 °C), suggesting the possibility that the desolvation might be a single-crystal to single-crystal transformation.
elements.clean_text: Crystals of 1-Zn - PhNO  2  subjected to guest removal appear shiny and crystalline; 1H NMR analysis showed that these desolvated crystals contained only 1-Zn. We monitored the removal of  guest molecules by TGA (Figure a), which showed that complete loss of nitrobenzene molecules occurred at 100-150 °C. The desolvated crystals were cooled to room temperature in the TGA instrument and used for powder X-ray diffraction analysis immediately. Interestingly, guest removal reverted the structure of the solvate to that of the unsolvated form of 1-Zn (Figure c). It should be noted that compounds 1-Zn and 1-Zn - PhNO  2  melt above 400 °C; the desolvated crystals are formed by solid-to-solid phase transition, not by cooling of the melt. We have not established the mechanism of this phase transition. We also observed desolvation of 1-Zn - PhNO  2  optically on a Fisher-Jones melting point apparatus. The crystals remained intact with no apparent change in morphology during the whole heating cycle (from 25 to 300 °C and back to 25 °C), suggesting the possibility that the desolvation might be a single-crystal to single-crystal transformation.

elements.content: We soaked these desolvated crystals (∼30 mg) in a small amount (0.2 mL) of nitrobenzene for 2 h and monitored the crystals under an optical microscope. We dried the soaked crystals on filter paper for 30 min (to remove any physisorbed nitrobenzene) and analyzed them with powder X-ray diffraction (Figure d) and TGA (Figure b). Analysis of the TGA results revealed that at least 74% of the 1-Zn crystals are resolvated with nitrobenzene during the 2 h of soaking. Powder X-ray analysis (Figure d) provided the unequivocal proof that the resolvation of 1-Zn with nitrobenzene indeed results in the formation of crystalline 1-Zn − PhNO2 . Optical microscopy showed that the crystals remained intact for the duration of soaking (see Figure S5 in the Supporting Information); we did not witness dissolution and regrowth of the crystals. These observations suggest that resolvation of 1-Zn with nitrobenzene to form 1-Zn − PhNO 2 is also a solid-to-solid transformation. We subjected these resolvated crystals to another cycle of heating in the TGA chamber; remarkably, desolvation occurred again as a solid-to-solid transformation to yield the crystals of 1-Zn (Figure e).
elements.clean_text: We soaked these desolvated crystals (~30 mg) in a small amount (0.2 mL) of nitrobenzene for 2 h and monitored the crystals under an optical microscope. We dried the soaked crystals on filter paper for 30 min (to remove any physisorbed nitrobenzene) and analyzed them with powder X-ray diffraction (Figure d) and TGA (Figure b). Analysis of the TGA results revealed that at least 74% of the 1-Zn crystals are resolvated with nitrobenzene during the 2 h of soaking. Powder X-ray analysis (Figure d) provided the unequivocal proof that the resolvation of 1-Zn with nitrobenzene indeed results in the formation of crystalline 1-Zn - PhNO2 . Optical microscopy showed that the crystals remained intact for the duration of soaking (see Figure S5 in the Supporting Information); we did not witness dissolution and regrowth of the crystals. These observations suggest that resolvation of 1-Zn with nitrobenzene to form 1-Zn - PhNO  2  is also a solid-to-solid transformation. We subjected these resolvated crystals to another cycle of heating in the TGA chamber; remarkably, desolvation occurred again as a solid-to-solid transformation to yield the crystals of 1-Zn (Figure e).

elements.content: Although contacts between Zn (and other metal) ions and O atoms of nitro groups are seen in crystals before, we have used the Zn···NO2 recognition as a synthon in the creation of coordination polymers with predetermined topology. We also showed that these polymers can intercalate nitrobenzene molecules (with some degree of selectivity) because of the aromatic groups that partition the interlayer space. There are only a few examples of porphyrin coordination polymers in which the network structure is intact after the guest removal. The coordination polymers reported in this work are built on weak coordination bonds in Zn···NO2 recognition; yet the networks retain their structure even after deintercalation and reintercalation with nitrobenzene molecules. These compounds also retain their overall crystallinity and macroscopic morphology through these reversible solid-to-solid transformations. Compound 1-Zn is thermally stable and soluble in organic solvents; we expect that exploration of noncoordinating aryl groups on the metalloporphyrin core may lead to the design of processable porous materials that can be used as potential sensors for nitrated and other aromatic compounds.
elements.clean_text: Although contacts between Zn (and other metal) ions and O atoms of nitro groups are seen in crystals before, we have used the Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition as a synthon in the creation of coordination polymers with predetermined topology. We also showed that these polymers can intercalate nitrobenzene molecules (with some degree of selectivity) because of the aromatic groups that partition the interlayer space. There are only a few examples of porphyrin coordination polymers in which the network structure is intact after the guest removal. The coordination polymers reported in this work are built on weak coordination bonds in Zn⋅⋅⋅NO2 recognition; yet the networks retain their structure even after deintercalation and reintercalation with nitrobenzene molecules. These compounds also retain their overall crystallinity and macroscopic morphology through these reversible solid-to-solid transformations. Compound 1-Zn is thermally stable and soluble in organic solvents; we expect that exploration of noncoordinating aryl groups on the metalloporphyrin core may lead to the design of processable porous materials that can be used as potential sensors for nitrated and other aromatic compounds.

elements.content: Synthesis, powder X-ray diffraction, and thermal analysis of 1-Zn and 1-Zn − PhNO 2 , and microscopic images of resolvation of 1-Zn crystals as a PDF file and single-crystal data as a CIF file. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

(b) Interlayer stacking showing the intercalation of nitrobenzene between the layers. Notice longer interlayer separation and shorter layer offset compared to 1-Zn (Figure ). Nitrobenzene molecules are plotted in lighter colors. H-atoms are omitted.

cln_elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of (a)1-Zn grown in chloroform solution, (b) 1-Zn − PhNO 2 grown in chloroform/nitrobenzene solution, (c) 1-Zn obtained by heating the 1-Zn−PhNO 2 to 350 °C, (d) mixture of 1-Zn and 1-ZnPhNO 2 obtained by soaking the crystals of desolvated 1-Zn in nitrobenzene, and (e) 1-Zn obtained by heating of the mixture in (d) to 350 °C. Note in (c) and (e) that the diffraction patterns of desolvated and re-desolvated crystals correspond to that of 1-Zn. Note in (d) the peaks corresponding to 1-Zn (open, blue circles) and 1-Zn − PhNO 2 (filled, red circles). Microscopic images of the crystals corresponding to the diffraction patterns are shown on the left. The image next to (d) is taken while the crystals are soaking in nitrobenzene. The image next to (e) shows some precipitation on crystal faces. The occlusion of smaller particles on well-grown crystals occurred when the soaked crystals are scraped on to a filter paper for drying. Morphology of the crystals remained unchanged during the heating in TGA chamber.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of (a)1-Zn grown in chloroform solution, (b) 1-Zn - PhNO  2  grown in chloroform/nitrobenzene solution, (c) 1-Zn obtained by heating the 1-Zn-PhNO 2  to 350 °C, (d) mixture of 1-Zn and 1-ZnPhNO  2  obtained by soaking the crystals of desolvated 1-Zn in nitrobenzene, and (e) 1-Zn obtained by heating of the mixture in (d) to 350 °C. Note in (c) and (e) that the diffraction patterns of desolvated and re-desolvated crystals correspond to that of 1-Zn. Note in (d) the peaks corresponding to 1-Zn (open, blue circles) and 1-Zn - PhNO  2  (filled, red circles). Microscopic images of the crystals corresponding to the diffraction patterns are shown on the left. The image next to (d) is taken while the crystals are soaking in nitrobenzene. The image next to (e) shows some precipitation on crystal faces. The occlusion of smaller particles on well-grown crystals occurred when the soaked crystals are scraped on to a filter paper for drying. Morphology of the crystals remained unchanged during the heating in TGA chamber.

cln_elements.content: TGA plots of (a) the solution grown crystals of1-Zn − PhNO 2 and (b) the mixture of 1-Zn and 1-Zn − PhNO 2 obtained by soaking the crystals of 1-Zn in nitrobenzene for 2 h. The 23.3% weight loss in (a) corresponds to the complete desolvation of nitrobenzene from 1-Zn − PhNO 2 (calculated weight loss:  23.6%). The 18.5% weight loss in (b) indicates that the mixture contains 74.4% of 1-Zn − PhNO 2 and 25.6% of 1-Zn.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  TGA plots of (a) the solution grown crystals of1-Zn - PhNO  2  and (b) the mixture of 1-Zn and 1-Zn - PhNO  2  obtained by soaking the crystals of 1-Zn in nitrobenzene for 2 h. The 23.3% weight loss in (a) corresponds to the complete desolvation of nitrobenzene from 1-Zn - PhNO  2  (calculated weight loss: 23.6%). The 18.5% weight loss in (b) indicates that the mixture contains 74.4% of 1-Zn - PhNO  2  and 25.6% of 1-Zn.

metadata.title:
Layered Porphyrin Coordination Polymers Based on Zinc···Nitro Recognition: 
Reversible Intercalation of Nitrobenzene
